questions.text: Diascopy can be used for clinical examination of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D: All of the above - Diascopy can be utilized to evaluate all these conditions. It helps in differentiating vascular lesions, which blanch when pressure is applied, from hemorrhagic ones, which do not.

 

Diascopy/Vitropression: It involves pressing a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colourless piece of plastic onto the skin to cause blanching by compressing blood out of small vessels. This allows other colours to be evaluated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Purpura - Diascopy is used to determine whether red or purple skin lesions are blanchable. Purpuric lesions do not blanch when pressure is applied, helping to distinguish them from lesions that are due to vasodilation.

 

Option B. Lupus Vulgaris - This is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis. A positive diascopy test in lupus vulgaris shows apple jelly nodules, which are a characteristic finding.

 

Option C. Nevus Anemicus - This is a congenital condition characterized by localized areas of skin that do not have normal vasomotor responses. Diascopy can demonstrate that the lesions blanch with pressure and match the surrounding skin because they do not contain more blood vessels, but rather less responsive ones.

 

 

Blanching response with Diascopy can be seen in below image:

 

 

 

(a) Brown-reddish infiltrated scaly plaques on the auricle and periauricular area,

(b) Diascopic examination showing the presence of light-brownish or “apple jelly” coloured nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diascopy is a clinical test used to evaluate blanching of skin lesions and can be applied to a variety of conditions including purpura, lupusvulgaris, and nevusanemicus to assess the nature of skin discoloration.

 

http://www.odermatol.com/issue-in-html/2017-1-7-lupus/


Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume I Chapter 4 Page No 4.19

questions.text: All of the following are primary skin lesions EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Crust

 

Option D: Crusts or scabs consist of dried-up discharge from the lesions. These are secondary skin lesions.

 

Papule, Vesicle, & Purpura are primary skin lesions.

 

Primary lesions of the skin include:
 

  • Papule Plaque Nodule
  • Vesicle Bulla
  • Macule Patch
  • Pustule Abscess
  • Petechiae Purpura Ecchymosis
  • Wheal


 

 

 

 

 

 

Secondary lesions of the skin include:
 

  • Lichenification
  • Erosion / Excoriation
  • Atrophy
  • Fissure
  • Scale
  • Ulcer
  • Crust
  • Induration
  • Scar

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Crusts are secondary skin lesions resulting from the maturation and subsequent changes to primary lesions such as vesicles or pustules, or from trauma to the skin, and are not the initial manifestation of a skin pathology.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 4 Page No 4.10

questions.text: All of the following are secondary skin lesions EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wheal

 

Explanation:

 

Lichenification, Fissure, & Ulcer are secondary skin lesions.

 

Wheal is a primary skin lesion.

 

 

Primary lesions of the skin include:
 

  • Papule Plaque Nodule
  • Vesicle Bulla
  • Macule Patch
  • Pustule Abscess
  • Petechiae Purpura Ecchymosis
  • Wheal

 

Secondary lesions of the skin include:
 

  • Lichenification
  • Erosion / Excoriation
  • Atrophy
  • Fissure
  • Scale
  • Ulcer
  • Crust
  • Induration
  • Scar

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A wheal is a primary lesion characterized by transient, raised, and often itchy areas on the skin due to an allergic reaction, unlike lichenification, fissures, and ulcers, which are secondary lesions resulting from the modification of primary lesions or externaldamage to the skin

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume I Chapter 4 Page No 4.10

questions.text: Match the options in Column A with the correct options in Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

Explanation:

Option B. Branny - This term is often used to describe the fine scales that resemble bran, the layers that flake off in pityriasisversicolor, a fungal infection of the skin.

 

Scales are visible exfoliation of the skin consists of flakes of stratum corneum. Parakeratosis refers to the presence of nucleated keratinocytes in the stratum corneum. It is indicative of a high turnover of keratinocytes. The scales represent compacted desquamated layers of stratum corneum, so Parakeratosis can be found in these skin lesions on Biopsy.

 

Silvery - This type of scale is most associated with psoriasis. Psoriasis scales are typically silver-white and can be found as thick, plaque-like lesions on the skin.

 

Mica - This type of scale is not a commonly used dermatological term but in the context of this question, it seems to be paired with pityriasis Lichenoideschronica, a rare skin disorder characterized by small, scaling papules.

 

Collarette - This describes the scaling that is seen with Pityriasis Rosea, where the scale is attached at the periphery of the lesion, creating a collarette appearance.

 

Various types of scales are given in below images.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: This below given lesion may be described as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Discoid

 

Option B: A Discoid/Nummular (coin-like) lesion is what is depicted in the given image, which is a round lesion without a central clearing.

 

The centre and the edge are both equally coloured and active. Psoriasis and discoid eczema both exhibit it.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Annular lesions are ring shaped with central clearing i.e., only the edges are active & appear raised, or in different colour. It is present in granuloma annulare and tinea corporis.

 

 

Option C. Nodular - Nodular lesions are raised bumps that extend into the dermal layer or below. They can be associated with conditions like nodular melanoma.

 

Option D. Ecchymosis - This term refers to a large bruise, which is a purplish patch resulting from extravasation of blood into the skin, often after trauma.

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Annular lesions have a ring shape, discoid lesions are coin-like, nodular lesions are palpable and extend into the dermis or subcutis, and ecchymosis represents a larger area of hemorrhage into the skin.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume I Chapter 4. Page No 4.11, 4.13

questions.text: Target Lesions are found in?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythema Multi Forme (EMF)

 

Option B: Erythema Multi Forme (EMF) –

  • This is a hypersensitivity reaction usually triggered by infections or drugs. The hallmark lesion of EMF is the target lesion, which has three concentric zones: a dusky central area, a paleredematous zone, and a peripheral red halo.

                        

  • Etiology:

Infections: HSV-1 (most  common), Mycoplasma Pneumoniae;

Drugs:Anti-malarials, NSAIDs, Sulphonamides;

Connective tissue Disorders: SLE;

Neoplasia: Leukemia, Internal Malignancy

  • Distribution: Distal Extremities;
  • Treatment: Treat the Underlying Cause & Steroids

 

Atypical target lesions with only 2 zones may be seen in Stevens Johnson Syndrome (SJS) & Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN)

 

  • Target lesions, also known as iris lesions, are characteristic of Erythema Multi Forme (EMF). They are named for their bulls eye appearance, which includes multiple concentric rings with central duskiness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tinea –
 

  • Tinea refers to fungal skin infections (ringworm), which can have an annular appearance but do not typically form the classic target or iris lesions associated with EMF.

 

Option C. Psoriasis –
 

  • Psoriasis lesions are typically Well-Demarcated, Erythematous Plaques with silvery scales. They do not present as target lesions.

 

Option D. Scabies –
 

  • The lesions caused by scabies are usually Small, Red, Itchy Bumps and Burrows in the skin. They do not display the target-like appearance of EMF lesions.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Erythema Multiforme is characterized by the presence of target lesions, which are distinctive, round lesions with concentric rings of color change.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume I Chapter 4. Page No 4.11, 4.13

questions.text: Which of the following disease has a dermatomal distribution of cutaneous lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Zoster

 

Option A: Herpes Zoster - Also known as shingles, this disease is caused by the reactivation of the Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV), which remains latent in the dorsal root ganglia after a primary chickenpox infection. Upon reactivation, the virus causes a painful rash that is typically limited to one dermatome, a specific area of the skin innervated by a single nerve.

Herpes zoster has a Dermatomal /Zosteriform distribution.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Herpes Genitalis - This condition is caused by the herpes simplex virus (usually type 2, and sometimes type 1). The lesions are vesicular and ulcerative but are not distributed along dermatomes; they are localized to the genital and surrounding areas.

 

In Herpes labialis & genitalis, which are produced by Herpes simplex viruses, grouped vesicles can be seen near lips & genitalia respectively.

 

Option C. Incontinentiapigmenti - This is a genetic disorder affecting the skin, hair, teeth, and nails, often with swirled patterns of discoloration on the skin. It does not follow a dermatomal distribution.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis - This is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrixschenckii, typically contracted from soil or plant matter. The cutaneous form of sporotrichosis is characterized by nodular lesions along the lymphatic channels, not by dermatomal distribution.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes zoster is the condition among the options provided that is associated with a dermatomal distribution of cutaneous lesions, following the pathway of a single spinal or cranial sensory nerve.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology in General Medicine 8th Edition, Pages 39-41

questions.text: Poikiloderma is a Triad of all EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auspitz Sign

 

Option B: Auspitz sign is seen in chronic plaque psoriasis, it is not associated with poikiloderma.

 

Explanation:

 

Poikiloderma is a special skin lesion with a triad of features {ATP}
 

  • Atrophy of skin
  • Telangiectasia (Permanently Dilated Blood Vessels)
  • Pigment Abnormalities (Dyspigmentation, both Hypo & Hyper)

 

 

Poikiloderma may be congenital or acquired. It is associated with Mycosis Fungoides, Dermatomyositis, Xeroderma Pigmentosum etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Poikiloderma is characterized by a triad of changes: pigment abnormalities, telangiectasia, and atrophy of the skin.
  • The Auspitz sign is not part of this triad but is associated with psoriasis

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume I Chapter 4 Page No 4.12

questions.text: All of the following diseases may be diagnosed by Tzanck smear EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Psoriasis

 

Option A: Psoriasis is diagnosed using clinical examination (Auspitz Sign) & Histopathological findings. Tzanck smear does NOT have any role in its diagnosis.

 

Psoriasis is a Chronic Inflammatory skin condition characterized by Erythematous Plaques with Silvery Scales. Diagnosis is typically made clinically and sometimes by biopsy, but a Tzanck smear is not used for its diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bullous Impetigo - Tzanck smear can be used to diagnose bullous impetigo by demonstrating Acantholytic cells, aiding in differentiating it from other blistering diseases.

 

Option C. Herpes Zoster - The Tzanck smear is useful in identifying Multinucleated Giant Cells and Acantholytic Cells.

 

Option D. Pemphigus - This Autoimmune Blistering disorder can be tentatively diagnosed with a Tzanck smear by finding Acantholytic cells, which are detached individual Keratinocytes.

 

Some important findings on Tzanck Smear are as follows:

 

The Frenchman Tzanck invented the Tzanck smear, a cheap, easy-to-use bedside cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular, and bullous diseases, particularly herpes.

 

Several techniques can be used to stain Tzanck smears, but Giemsa stain is the most popular.

 

Haematoxylin and Eosin, Wright, Methylene Blue, Papanicolaou, and Toluidine Blue are additional stains that are employed.

 

Image: Tzanck smear, showing multinucleated giant cells in center

 

 

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Tzanck_test.png

 

EducationalObjective:

 

  • The Tzanck smear is a cytological test used to diagnose blistering skin diseases such as Herpes Zoster, Pemphigus, and Bullous Impetigo by demonstrating characteristic cellular changes. It is not used for the diagnosis of psoriasis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume I Chapter 3 Page No 3.25

questions.text: Woods Lamp used for diagnosis of Dermatological Disorders, what is the Wavelength used in it?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 320-400

 

Option C: 320-400nm

 

This is the UVA range and is the correct wavelength for a Wood's lamp. UVA is less damaging and is able to show certain skin conditions due to the fluorescence that some substances emit under this light.

 

 

  • Woods lamp: It uses ultraviolet wavelength light, 320-400nm (peak 365nm).
  • Filter of woods lamp is made up of Barium silicate & 9% Nickel oxide.
  • It is used in dermatology to detect several conditions based on how the light is absorbed or reflected by the skin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 200-240nm –

  • This wavelength corresponds to far-UVC, which is not used in Wood's lamps due to its potential to cause corneal damage and is absorbed by the ozone layer.

 

Option B. 280-300nm –

  • This range includes UVB, which is not typically used in Wood's lamps either. UVB has a shorter wavelength and is more associated with DNAdamage than UVA.

 

Option D. 500-700 nm –

  • This range is in the visible light spectrum, specifically green to red light, and is not used in Wood's lamps.

 

Different disorders will produce different color fluorescence by using woods lamp.

 

Table: Various Diseases & their colour on Woods Lamp Examination

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Wood's lamp uses UVA light with a wavelength of 365nm (320-400 nm) for the diagnosis of various skin conditions based on the fluorescence characteristics of the skin under this specific range of ultraviolet light.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume I Chapter 4 Page No 4.20

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition, Chapter 26 Page No 26.40

Image source: https://dermnetnz.org/assets/Uploads/bacterial/erythrasma13__WatermarkedWyJXYXRlcm1hcmtlZCJd.jpg

.

choices.text: Adult Phase of Atopic Dermatitis

questions.text: Which of the following diseases has Extensor Involvement?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psoriasis

 

Option C: Psoriasis

  • It is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by the formation of raised, red, and scaly plaques, often affecting extensor surfaces such as elbows and knees.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Herpes Zoster

  • It typically presents with a painful rash that follows a dermatomal pattern, affecting sensory nerves, and does not involve extensor surfaces.

 

 

Option B. Lichen Planus

  • It is a chronic inflammatory condition that mainly affects the skin and mucous membranes, causing flat-topped, itchy papules and typically involve flexor surfaces.

 

Option D. Adult Phase of Atopic Dermatitis

  • It involves flexor surfaces and is characterized by eczematous lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin disease that often affects extensor surfaces such as elbows and knees, making it distinct from other skin conditions mentioned in the options.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 4.6

questions.text: Which of the following is a Primary Skin Lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bulla

 

Option D: Bulla
 

  • It is a primary skin lesion that is a fluid-filled blister larger than 5mm in diameter, which forms within or beneath the epidermis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atrophy
 

  • It is a secondary skin lesion characterized by thinning of the skin layers and loss of tissue substance.

 

Option B. Crust
 

  • It is a secondary lesion formed from the dried exudate of serum, blood, or pus on the skin surface.

 

Option C. Fissure
 

  • It is a secondary lesion that refers to a linear crack or split in the skin, often due to dryness or excessive dry skin.

 

Primary lesions of the skin include:
 

  • Papule Plaque Nodule
  • Vesicle Bulla
  • Macule Patch
  • Pustule Abscess
  • Petechiae Purpura Ecchymosis
  • Wheal

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Secondary lesions of the skin include:
 

  • Lichenification
  • Erosion / Excoriation
  • Atrophy
  • Fissure
  • Scale
  • Ulcer
  • Crust
  • Induration
  • Scar

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A primary skin lesion, such as a Bulla, represents an initial and distinct skin abnormality, whereas secondary skin lesions, like crusts or fissures, result from the evolution or manipulation of primary lesions.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 4.13

questions.text: A 25-year-old female is presenting with the special lesions as shown in the below image. What are these lesions called as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Comedones

 

Option A: Above given image is showing comedones which are seen in ACNE VULGARIS.

 

Explanation:

 

ACNE VULGARIS:
 

  • Most common form of acne.
  • Most characteristic lesion - Comedones.
  • Most severe form of acne vulgaris - Grade IV / Nodulocystic Acne.
  • Most severe form of acne - Acne conglobata.

 

Comedones (are considered as special lesions) are the specific lesions of acne vulgaris
 

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. Comedonal lesions are the Earliest lesions of acne. They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct.

 

When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedone or white head.
 

When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidised by the air & turns black which is known as open comedone (blackhead)

 

Stages of acne

 

 

According to Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne, Oral isotretinoin is indicated for the treatment of severe acne.

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

Image: global alliance algorithm for improving outcomes in acne

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Comedones are small, non-inflamed lesions found in acne, characterized by a plug of sebum and keratin within a hair follicle, presenting as blackheads or whiteheads.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 Page No 90.1, 90.10, 90.13, 90.32 & 90.37

choices.text: Burrows are present mainly in Stratum Corneum
Itching Worsens in the Night
Animal Scabies is characterized by Burrows
5% Permethrin Cream from Neck to Toe in Adults & from Head to Toe in Children is Topical Agent of Choice

questions.text: All the statements are true about scabies EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Animal Scabies is characterised by Burrows.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused by the Sarcoptes scabei var hominis / Itch mite / Sarcoptes scabei.

 

 

  • The incubation period of scabies is 3-4 weeks (21-28 days)
  • However, reinfection of a previously cured individual may provoke immediate symptoms.
  • Itching worsens at night & when the patient is warm (Option B). Nocturnal pruritus is the most common symptom associated with scabies.
  • Water-washed diseases, such as scabies, are infections brought on by poor personal hygiene and a lack of access to clean water.
  • The distinctive signs include intense itching and shallow burrows.
  • Burrows in scabies are typically found in the stratum corneum as depicted in the below image. (Option A)

 

 

In most people the trails of the burrowing mites appear brownish linear or s shaped tracks in the skin & occur as a result of excavation of the adult mite in the epidermis.

 

S shaped track, pointed with black arrows in the below image.

 

 

  • Burrows are absent in animal scabies. (Option C)
  • Lesions are found in the Circle of Hebra (imaginary line formed by connecting the sites of involvement in scabies like, web spaces, feet, ventral wrists, elbows, cack, breasts, buttocks & external genitals).
  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults & from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) & pregnant women. (Option D)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While human scabies involves burrow formation in the skin, animal scabies does not typically lead to burrow formation when transmitted to humans.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 Page No 34.39-34.47

choices.text: Erythema Multiforme (EMF) is the diagnosis
Erythema Multiforme Minor is the most common form
The distribution of Target Lesions is mainly over Acral Sites
NSAIDs are the most common Triggering Factor for EMF

questions.text: All of the following are correct about the below given condition EXCEPT.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) NSAIDs are the most common Triggering Factor for EMF

 

Option D: The given image shows characteristic target lesions of Erythema Multiforme (EMF) (Option A), which most commonly occurs following a herpes simplex virus infection (NOT due to drugs)

 

Explanation:

 

Erythema Multiforme: Self-limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from Delayed type of hypersensitivity. It most commonly occurs following an Infection>> Drug intake.

 

Clinical Features: Classic Acral iris or 'target lesions'.

 

 

  • Lesions are distributed preferentially on the Distal Extremities (Option C). Oral and genital mucosal membranes lesions are associated with Erosions.
  • The lesions appear in successive crops for a few days and fade in 1-2 weeks, sometimes leaving Dusky Discoloration.

 

The common triggers are:
 

  • Herpes Simplex Infection (Most Common) (Option D)
  • Mycoplasma Infection
  • Bacterial Infections
  • Fungal Infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy- Carcinoma, Lymphoma, Leukaemia
  • Drugs- Sulphonamides, Rifampicin, Penicillin’s, Hydantoin derivatives
  • Miscellaneous- Lupus Erythematosus (Rowell Syndrome), Sarcoidosis, Polyarteritis Nodosa

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythema Multiforme is often triggered by infections, particularly herpes simplex virus, rather than NSAIDs, and it commonly presents as Erythema Multiforme minor with target lesions concentrated on acral sites.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 47, Page No 47.1-5

questions.text: An elderly person presented with lesions as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herpes Zoster.

 

Option C: Herpes Zoster.
 

  • Herpes zoster, also known as shingles, is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus and presents with painful, grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, following a dermatomal distribution, as shown in the image.
  • This pattern is characteristic of herpes zoster.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chickenpox
 

  • Chickenpox, caused by the varicella-zoster virus, typically presents with a pruritic, vesicular rash that starts on the face and trunk and spreads to the rest of the body.
  • The lesions appear in crops and are at different stages of healing.
  • The rash in the image does not display this typical distribution or the various stages of healing.

 

Option B: Contact Dermatitis
 

  • Contact Dermatitis is an inflammatory skin condition caused by contact with a substance that triggers an allergic or irritant response.
  • It presents with Erythema, Edema, and sometimes Vesicles, but these are not typically in a dermatomal distribution.

 

Option D: Lichen Planus
 

  • Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin and mucous membranes.
  • It presents with pruritic, flat-topped, violaceous papules and plaques with fine white lines (Wickham's striae) on the surface.

 

 

  • The rash in the image does not exhibit these features.
     

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes zoster can be identified by its distinctive clustered vesicular eruption within a single dermatome, which is typically unilateral and does not cross the midline.
  • This presentation is especially common in elderly or immunocompromised individuals due to the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 25.27

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 4, 1412

choices.text: Relaxed Skin Tension Lines

questions.text: Identify the following lines.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blaschko Lines

 

Option D:
 

  • Blaschko lines are an intricate and unique pattern of skin markings that follow a specific distribution on the human body.
  • They are thought to represent the migration and proliferation of embryonic cells during early development.
  • They are not visible under normal circumstances and only become apparent when certain skin conditions or genetic disorders manifest.

 

 

Epidermal Nevi: Multiple Verrucous Hyperpigmented Plaques that clearly follow the Lines of Blaschko Note the Midline Demarcation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hinderer’s Lines
 

  • Two Intersecting Lines, one drawn from the Ala to the Tragus and other from the Lateral Canthus to the Oral Commissure.

 

 

Option B. Marionette Lines/Melomental Folds:
 

  • They are consequences of Facial Ageing.
  • They are curvilinear wrinkles formed because of facial movements & the ageing process.
  • They extend downwards from the Oral Commisures.

 

 

Option C. Relaxed Skin Tension Lines/RSTL
 

  • They run perpendicular to the direction of contraction of the underlying muscles & parallel to the dermal collagen bundles.
  • To produce favourable aesthetic results, incisions should generally be designed to follow RSTL as the resulting scars will be stronger & less likely to stretch.

 

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No. 7.7, 20.1

Online resources: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19021675/

https://journals.lww.com/cddr/Fulltext/2017/01010/Lines_in_Dermatology.8.aspx

questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-e, 2-c, 3-d, 4-b

 

Option B:

 

  • Woods lamp: It uses ultraviolet wavelength light, 320-400nm (Peak 365nm).

  • Filter of woods lamp is made up of Barium silicate & 9% Nickel Oxide.

  • It is used in dermatology to detect several conditions based on how the light is absorbed or reflected by the skin.

 

Correct matches:

 

 

 

 

 

 

Table: Various diseases & their colour on woods lamp examination

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Wood's lamp uses UVA light with a wavelength of 365nm (320-400 nm) for the diagnosis of various skin conditions based on the fluorescence characteristics of the skin under this specific range of ultraviolet light.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume I Chapter 4 Page No 4.20

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition, Chapter 26 Page No 26.40

choices.text: Bacterial Meningitis
Hand Foot and Mouth Disease
Tubercular Meningitis
Herpes Simplex Infection

questions.text: A child was admitted with complaints of fever, neck rigidity (meningitis features) with associated oral erosions and skin manifestations as shown in the picture. CSF analysis show normal glucose, proteins and lymphocytes increased. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Herpes Simplex Infection

 

Option D:
 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) can cause meningitis, especially HSV-2.
  • The presence of oral erosions and skin lesions which are grouped vesicles, resembling herpetic vesicles, alongside signs of meningitis, and CSF analysis showing normal glucose, normal protein, and increased lymphocytes is indicative of HSV infection, not bacterial or tubercular meningitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bacterial Meningitis
 

  • This typically presents with high fever, neck rigidity, and altered mental status.
  • CSF analysis often shows elevated white cells (usually neutrophils), low glucose, and high proteins, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease
 

  • It is usually caused by Cox-Sackie virus and primarily affects children.
  • It presents with oral ulcers and a rash on the hands and feet, but it is not commonly associated with meningitis.

 

Option C. Tubercular Meningitis
 

  • It would generally present with a chronic course of fever and neck rigidity.
  • CSF analysis in tubercular meningitis often shows low glucose, elevated proteins, and lymphocytosis, which does not align with the findings presented.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes simplex infection in a pediatric patient presenting with fever, neck rigidity, oral erosions, characteristic skin manifestations, and CSF findings consistent with viral meningitis.
  • The recognition of oral and skin lesions typical of herpes simplex is crucial in differentiating it from other causes of meningitis.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.16

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1368

questions.text: Treatment of this condition in a Pregnant Female would be?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryotherapy.

 

Option C: Cryotherapy and Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) are the preferred treatment modalities for genital warts in pregnant women as they are considered safer options during pregnancy.

 

 

The clinical image displays verrucous / rough surfaced lesion over female genitalia, which is suggestive of Condyloma acuminata / Genital warts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Podophyllin
 

  • It is not recommended during pregnancy as it is considered teratogenic and should be avoided due to potential harm to the developing fetus.

 

Option B. Imiquimod
 

  • It is also not advised during pregnancy as it may pose a risk to the fetus.

 

Option D. Surgical Excision

 

  • This is generally not the first-line treatment for condyloma acuminata (genital warts) in pregnancy due to the potential for bleeding and scarring.
  • This can be treatment modality used in Giant Genital warts like Buschke Lowenstein Tumours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pregnant females with Condyloma Acuminata (Genital Warts), the preferred treatment option is Cryotherapy or Trichloroacetic Acid (TCA) as they are safe and effective, while options like Podophyllin and Imiquimod should be avoided due to their teratogenic potential.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 112.29

choices.text: Multinucleated Giant Cells are seen in Varicella-Zoster Infections.
Tzanck Cells are Keratinocytes
Acantholytic Cells are seen in Pemphigus Vulgaris
It is the most Accurate Test for Pemphigus Vulgaris

questions.text: All of the following are correct about Tzanck smear findings EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is the most Accurate Test for Pemphigus Vulgaris.

 

Option D. Direct Immuno Fluorescence Microscopy (DIF) is the most accurate test for Pemphigus vulgaris, NOT Tzanck Smear.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck Smear are seen in Varicella-Zoster and Herpes Simplex Infections.
 

  • The Frenchman Tzanck invented the Tzanck smear, a cheap, easy-to-use bedside cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular, and bullous diseases, particularly herpes.
  • Several techniques can be used to stain Tzanck smears, but Giemsa stain is the most popular.
  • Haematoxylin and eosin, Wright, Methylene Blue, Papanicolaou, and Toluidine Blue are additional stains that are employed.

 

Results in Tzanck Smear:

 

Option B. Tzanck cells / Acantholytic cells are Keratinocytes.
 

  • They are seen in vesiculobullous disorders, as a result of acantholysis.
  • The keratinocytes lose their polyhedral shapes and characteristically become round with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and an abundance of basophilic cytoplasm.
  • Due to the cytoplasm's propensity to condense at the cell's periphery and create a perinuclear halo, the basophilic staining is more pronounced peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells).

 

Some important findings on Tzanck smear are as follows:
 

 

Image: Tzanck smear, showing multinucleated giant cells in center

 

 

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Tzanck_test.png

 

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

 

Option D. This clinical picture is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. The first line investigation is Tzanck smear.

 

  • It allows us to visualize the histology by collecting material from the floor of a fresh blister that is stained with Giemsa or any Romanowsky stain.
  • Tzanck cells are seen on microscopy.
  • Direct Immuno Fluorescence Microscopy (DIF) is the most accurate test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Tzanck smear can show multinucleated giant cells in varicella-zoster infections and acantholytic cells in Pemphigus vulgaris, but it is not the most accurate test for Pemphigus vulgaris; that distinction belongs to direct immunofluorescence.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 3.25, 50.4-50.8
